journal-meta.journal-title: Ergonomics in Design: The Quarterly of Human Factors Applications

title-group.article-title: Principles for Designing Good User Interfaces

body.p: The following is a list of ideas and principles to keep in mind when designing a comprehensive user interface.

sec.title: Minimize scrolling
sec.p: There is evidence that scrolling negatively affects the comprehension of complex text in online environments (Sanchez & Wiley, 2009). This negative impact with scrolling is found to be more prevalent among individuals with low working memory capacity, potentially because of their difficulty in integrating information regularly or because of disorientation during reading. The authors suggest that in order to promote better learning, Web page designers should organize information in paginated form with meaningful subheadings.

sec.title: Use the appropriate feedback display
sec.p: Users prefer to be informed about the progress of the system, even if the wait time seems to appear unreasonable (Branaghan & Sanchez, 2009). Constant-rate progress bars are better than static text and sequential dots, both in terms of generating user preference and creating the perception of a reasonable wait time. When designers are unable to determine how long computing operations will last, it is recommended that a constant-rate progress bar be used that starts out by underestimating the progress of the operation and updates quickly at the end. There is evidence that fast progress at the very end of a progress bar increases user satisfaction. Other mechanisms to improve user preference are reducing the tempo of the changes in a sequential dot display and adding some movement to a static feedback display.

sec.title: Capitalize on multiple modalities for time-critical tasks
sec.p: When designing displays for domains involving time-critical tasks, use trimodal displays (which are a combination of visual, audio, and tactile displays), which, unlike single-modality displays, have the potential to contribute to best operator performance by providing multisensory information that is redundant or complimentary (e.g., Oskarsson, Ericksson, & Carlander, 2012).

sec.title: Use a color scale that is appropriate for the data visualization task
sec.p: Multicolored scales support better speed and accuracy than brightness scales for identifi cation tasks (e.g., determining the temperature of a certain city in a weather display), whereas brightness scales support better performance for comparison tasks (e.g., determining which of the two cities is colder). Performance on identifi cation tasks requires a visual search of the legend and is dependent on users’ ability to discriminate between colors, and this is best achieved using multicolored scales. On the other hand, performance on comparison tasks is dependent on users’ ability to directly compare two colors on the visualization without referring to the legend, and this is best achieved using brightness scales.
